channel.title: Events on tracker
channel.description: Recent content in Events on tracker

item.title: Docker Detroit, Wednesday July 22, 2015, 6:00 pm, Troy, Michigan
item.description:
I hope to see you at Docker Detroit’s kickoff meeting, to be held at RIIS, 1250 Stephenson Highway, Suite 200 in Troy, MI starting at 6:00 p.m. tonight July 22 2015. I’ll be coming in from Ann Arbor. The venue is between 14 Mile and Maple behind Beaumont Hospital. Google Maps suggests that because of construction on I-75 in that area you might want to head north on Campbell instead of taking the I-75 / I-696 interchange north.

Leading the meeting tonight is Pepijn Bruienne from the University of Michigan. He will be speaking about “Docker in production” and organizing a group discussion with Q&A.

See the meetup announcement for more details, refreshments will be provided.

The meetup is hosted at RIIS a boutique web and mobile development house. Hope to see you there! I’ll be taking notes and plan to do a writeup of the event, as well as sharing my own experiences running Docker for ARM on a Raspberry PI 2.

item.title: A design for an an Ann Arbor events channel, @a2events
item.description:
Here's a design for a low overhead way to post about events coming up in Ann Arbor. Follow @a2events on Twitter if you want to play along.

The first rule of business is that every event has to have a URL, and the more simple and direct the URL is the more likely it is that it's authoritative for the event. If an event doesn't have a URL yet, I'll blog about it here if I need to post about it.

The second rule of business is that I'm not keeping a calendar, just a feed, and the feed is not going to be a 100% comprehensive feed; you have to be prepared to get events info from multiple sources and I'm just one of them.

The third rule of business of course is that if you want to pay for this service we'll find a way to let you pay, though the specifics are TBD.

My basic idea for technology is to use a tag on my Pinboard account to feed a specific tag, and to use that tag to feed IFTTT to feed Twitter so that events get pushed out. I'll probably also use a Node-RED page to help construct something that does the right thing, and there will be a Slack channel on the a2b3 slack to do - something.

Thanks to Brian Kerr for having the foresight to reserve the name a2events.

There will be a bounce house there; please chip in a dollar to help out with that.

item.title: Keeping up with area events: some Ann Arbor calendars
item.description:
Every Thursday at the a2b3 lunch, we talk about upcoming events for the next week and month and season for the Ann Arbor area. It's a good way to hear about what's coming up, and to hear from people who are organizing events in the future who need help now for planning and gaining support.

I've been unburdening my inbox of events notices by sending them out to Twitter. It strikes me that I could almost as easily do that here in this weblog, since there's an "events" category. The question is when you're trying to empty out an inbox what the quick path to "pass along the news" is, especially when you're not so well connected to the event that you might not even know enough to get the news promptly when things are cancelled.

The radio events calendar that I listen to is the WCBN-FM effort which is broadcast about eight times a day. wcbn.org/events.

The monthly print calendar that's the easiest to follow is the Ann Arbor Observer calendar, with such a following that its deadline schedule drives booking decisions at venues around town. The online iteration of it lives at annarborobserver.com

The online calendar that was comprehensive beyond belief came from the Ann Arbor Chronicle, who aggregated online calendars from dozens of venue calendars. The Chronicle is closing shop, and so the long term true home of its calendar may change. events.annarborchronicle.com

I've been super surprised at how useful Meetup.com has been to find out about events happening around you, and to publicize upcoming events to people who are interested but who you don't already know.

Word of mouth is always the best way to get the word out; you're welcome to join us for lunch Thursdays. Pay for your own lunch, we have introductions at 12:30 p.m., and events are last on the agenda that tries very hard to end at or about 1:00 p.m. www.meetup.com/a2b3-lunch

item.title: Ann Arbor DDA Operations Committee meeting agenda, Wednesday July 30, 2014, 11:00 a.m., 150 S Fifth Ave Ann Arbor
item.description:
Meeting of the DDA Operations Committee

Wednesday, July 30, 2014 at 11:00 AM

DDA Office 150 S. Fifth Ave, Suite 301

Suggested Agenda

 

 

 

1.      Ed Vielmetti, parking app demonstration

 

2.      Transportation

a.       Michael Ford AAATA – pedestrian walkway request

b.      WALLY downtown train station location recommendation

 

3.      Parking Operations

a.       DDA year to year comparison

b.      Art Fair 2014

c.       2014 summer parking structure repair/maintenance details

 

4.      New Business

a.       Ann & Ashley commercial space build out analysis 

 

5.      Old Business

a.       Status of ambassador program

 

6.      Construction

a.       Colliers Realty feedback on draft 4th & William commercial build out design and operations financial assumptions

item.title: U of Michigan to announce "historic event" at Michigan Stadium
item.description:
BREAKING: Special Event Press Conference today @ Noon (EDT). Historic event to be held at Michigan Stadium. #BigHouse

— Michigan Tix Office (@umichtix) April 4, 2014

The working assumption is that this is the long-rumored summer soccer game between Manchester United and Real Madrid in August. From Crain's Detroit:

Global soccer powerhouses Manchester United — wearing its new Chevrolet-sponsored jerseys — and Real Madrid will square off at Michigan Stadium in Ann Arbor at 4 p.m. Aug. 2, two sources with direct knowledge of the situation told Crain’s this week. The University of Michigan has scheduled a press conference for noon Friday to announce the game.

UPDATE: Confirmed.

#mufc face Real Madrid in the International Champions Cup, presented by @ChevroletFC. #mutour http://t.co/6bTkIaqdoJ pic.twitter.com/3DVqUwFD8q

— Manchester United (@ManUtd) April 4, 2014

item.title: April 2014 Web Analytics Wednesday at Enlighten, a meeting non-summary
item.description:
We had 11 in attendance for the April 2014 edition of the Ann Arbor Web Analytics Wednesday group, which meets roughly monthly at Enlighten on the west side of Ann Arbor. This month's meeting was sponsored by Tealium, a tag management vendor. Thanks to Chris Grant for being my co-organizer for the event.

I won't try to summarize what was said by whom in what order, because discussion went around and around the table a few times. What I will try to capture is some of the topics we talked about, or talked about wanting to talk about more at future meetings. This includes (in alphabetical order)

  • Adobe Business Catalyst
  • Adobe SiteCatalyst (formerly Omniture)
  • Clicktale
  • Clicky
  • Crazy Egg
  • Do you give people access to raw data?
  • Edward Tufte
  • Google Analytics
  • Michael Beasley's book on analytics, Practical Web Analytics for User Experience
  • Mousestats
  • Qualaroo
  • Radian6 from Salesforce
  • Stephen Few
  • Tealium tag management, this month's sponsor
  • Wolfram Language, for linguistic and sentiment analysis
  • analytics to inform application design
  • competitive analysis
  • confetti maps (from Crazy Egg)
  • correlogram to show what people do on your site
  • heat maps
  • information architecture
  • portfoliostud.io
  • social listening
  • stitching of user identity across devices
  • survey tools
  • tag management
  • user experience

If any of these terms resonate with you, please consider coming to a future Ann Arbor Web Analytics Wednesday! We organize with a Meetup group, or you can go to the Web Analytics Wednesday main page and find future dates.

item.title: Ann Arbor Mini Maker Faire, May 10, 2014, Washtenaw Community College
item.description:
Please share this Save the Date with your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues across the area.

Now in its sixth year, the Ann Arbor Mini Maker Faire features dozens of makers from across the region and draws over three thousand members of the community for the day’s free events. Metalworkers, inventors, papermakers, artists, students, robot designers, enthusiasts and professional alike teach the public how they make their work.

Many participants come away with more than just inspiration, but new skills they can use to fuel their own creations and lasting connections to other makers and resources in the region.

May 10, 2014 marks the second time the Ann Arbor Mini Maker Faire will be hosted by Washtenaw Community College. This free, all-ages event features community members of all types who come together to display their ideas, projects, and inventions.

We will be seeking applications from people and groups with engaging, inspiring, and just plain cool projects. Projects should have a focus on the process of creating, designing, and making - not just displaying a final product. Makers of all ages and experience levels are encouraged to submit applications. We will begin seeking applications for makers in the next few weeks.

More Info

Check out our website (http://www.a2makerfaire.com) or our Facebook page for more information, applications, and dates.

Organized by members of the Ann Arbor tech and arts communities such as a2geeks (http://www.a2geeks.com) and GO-Tech (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/notbago/), the Ann Arbor Mini Maker Faire is a small, local version of the huge Bay-area Maker Faire, and is one of many faires across the country that happen year around.

If you have any questions about participating in or attending the Mini Maker Faire, please visit http://www.a2makerfaire.com.

(Needs point of contact for questions via email)

item.title: For yet another year, I'm not at SXSW
item.description:
SXSW is "spring break for geeks". Every year the nerd bird flies hundreds of people from San Francisco to Austin (and to be fair other airplanes fly other people from other places to Austin). There's a good solid week of product demos, parties, music, film, etc.

It sounds like fun, and I've never gone. I'm wondering what my alternate history would have been if I would have been a regular there - who would I know that I don't know now, what connections I'd make, etc.

There are people who seem to exist solely to go to conferences. I'm not one of them. My peak conference-going era was that of Usenix annual conferences and occasional NSF workshops around the NSFnet. It's fun, but exhausting, and it's hard to square up being out and about with the simple requirements of taking care of family at home.

So enjoy SXSW 2014! Twitter all about it! Tell us what interesting new companies are going to have a breakout moment (or not), and save a seat for me next year (which I probably won't go to). I'm reminded that I didn't go in 2012 either.

if you're not at #sxsw let me summarize: utilikilt, ukulele, startup, kickball cancelled by rain, barbeque. #notatsxsw

— Edward Vielmetti (@vielmetti) March 11, 2012

Related articles
The Effects of SXSW on Austin Bar Tabs
We'll Be At SXSW 2014 Bringing You the Latest Coverage
10 Art Events to Check Out at SXSW 2014
SXSW Day 1: Gary Vaynerchuk Tells You How To 'Crush' SXSW
Where to Find Startups at SXSW 2014
NSFNET notepad in Cornell Notes style

item.title: Noam Chomsky, "Corporatization of the University", July 12, 2013 at Rackham Auditorium, University of Michigan Ann Arbor
item.description:
Noam Chomsky, an American linguist, philosopher, cognitive scientist, logician, historian, political critic, and activist, will be speaking about the Corporatization of the University for an hour on July 12th.  There will also be a question and answer session. 

Tickets are free to GEO/LEO members and to AAUP members. General admission is $5. For tickets see Eventbrite.

This event is co-sponsored by: American Association of University Professors-American Federation of Teachers Local 6075, American Federation of Teachers-Michigan, Coalition for Tuition Equality, Eastern Michigan University Federation of Teachers, Lecturers’ Employee Organization, 2013 Linguistics Institute of the Linguistic Society of America, UM Philosophy Department, and the Washtenaw Community Action Team.

Chomsky spoke on the topic of “Academic Freedom and the Corporatization of Universities” at the U of Toronto Scarborough in 2011; here’s a 90 minute speech. I don’t expect that this event will be a repeat.

The track ‘Noam Chomsky’ from the album ‘Trouble down south’ by The Horsies, on Austin Throwdown Records.

item.title: a2geeks 2013 annual meeting, Thursday May 16 2013, 5:30 p.m. at Ann Arbor SPARK
item.description:
From the Facebook event announcement:

a2geeks' third annual meeting is a gathering-of-the-geeks - inventors and innovators, makers and hackers, students and grandparents, town and gown. This event will also kick-off the A2Geeks Civic Apps Contest. Food and fun galore.

The event starts at 5:30 p.m. I'll be there pitching the Civic Apps contest, which I've been working on for a while now to organize. See you there!
